    • Method Detail

      • testForMean

        public static boolean testForMean(java.lang.String signStr,
                                  double hypoMean,
                                  DataDescription sampleDesc,
                                  double populationStddev,
                                  double alpha)
        This method conducts a Z test for one population mean when the population's standard deviation is known.
        Us knowing the population's standard deviation is kinda unrealistic but it does happen sometimes.
        This method will produce exact results (Z test) under the assumption that the population is approximately normally distributed.
        The null hypothesis is specified with the signStr parameter:
        • if signStr is "=" then H0: xPar = hypoMean
        • if signStr is ">=" then H0: xPar >= hypoMean
        • if signStr is "<=" then H0: xPar <= hypoMean
        Parameters:
        signStr - ">=", "<=" or "=" to specify the sign of the inequality in the null hypothesis
        hypoMean - the hypothesized mean
        sampleDesc - sample's description
        populationStddev - this sample's population's standard deviation
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        true if the null hypothesis is accepted (the alternative hypothesis is rejected)

      • testForMean

        public static boolean testForMean(java.lang.String signStr,
                                  double hypoMean,
                                  DataDescription sampleDesc,
                                  double alpha)
        This method conducts a T test for one population mean when the population's standard deviation is unknown.
        This method will produce approximate results by using this sample's standard deviation as it was the population's standard deviation. (Under the assumption that the population is approximately normally distributed.)
        The null hypothesis is specified with the signStr parameter:
        • if signStr is "=" then H0: xPar = hypoMean
        • if signStr is ">=" then H0: xPar >= hypoMean
        • if signStr is "<=" then H0: xPar <= hypoMean
        Parameters:
        signStr - ">=", "<=" or "=" to specify the sign of the inequality in the null hypothesis
        hypoMean - the hypothesized mean
        sampleDesc - sample's description
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        true if the null hypothesis is accepted (the alternative hypothesis is rejected)

      • testForMean

        public static boolean testForMean(java.lang.String signStr,
                                  double hypoMean,
                                  double sampleCount,
                                  double sampleMean,
                                  double sampleOrPopulationStddev,
                                  boolean stddevIsFromPopulation,
                                  double alpha)
        This method is a compact version of these two methods: testForMean(String, double, DataDescription, double), testForMean(String, double, DataDescription, double, double)
        The outcome depends on the `stddevIsFromPopulation` parameter since it will determine the distribution this method will use to calculate it's boundaries. (Z or T dist)
        Parameters:
        signStr - ">=", "<=" or "=" to specify the sign of the inequality in the null hypothesis
        hypoMean - the hypothesized mean
        sampleCount - number of terms in the sample
        sampleMean - sample's mean (x par)
        sampleOrPopulationStddev - a stddev value (can be from your sample or your population)
        stddevIsFromPopulation - specifies if the stddev entered was the population's or the sample's stddev value
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        true if the null hypothesis is accepted (the alternative hypothesis is rejected)

      • testForVariance

        public static boolean testForVariance(java.lang.String signStr,
                                      double hypoVariance,
                                      DataDescription sampleDesc,
                                      double alpha)
        This method conducts a Chi-Square test for one population variance.
        The null hypothesis is specified with the signStr parameter:
        • if signStr is "=" then H0: populationVariance = hypoVariance
        • if signStr is ">=" then H0: populationVariance >= hypoVariance
        • if signStr is "<=" then H0: populationVariance <= hypoVariance
        Parameters:
        signStr - ">=", "<=" or "=" to specify the sign of the inequality in the null hypothesis
        hypoVariance - the hypothesized variance
        sampleDesc - sample's description
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        true if the null hypothesis is accepted (the alternative hypothesis is rejected)

      • testForVariance

                                      double sampleCount,
                                      double sampleVariance,
                                      double alpha)

      • testForProportion

        public static boolean testForProportion(java.lang.String signStr,
                                        double hypoProportion,
                                        double sampleCount,
                                        double sampleProportion,
                                        double alpha)
        This method conducts a Z test for one population proportion.
        The null hypothesis is specified with the signStr parameter:
        • if signStr is "=" then H0: p = hypoProportion
        • if signStr is ">=" then H0: p >= hypoProportion
        • if signStr is "<=" then H0: p <= hypoProportion
        Parameters:
        signStr - ">=", "<=" or "=" to specify the sign of the inequality in the null hypothesis
        hypoProportion - the hypothesized proportion
        sampleCount - number of terms in this sample
        sampleProportion - sample's proportion value (successes / count)
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        true if the null hypothesis is accepted (the alternative hypothesis is rejected)

      • testForDiffOfMeansKnown

        public static boolean testForDiffOfMeansKnown(java.lang.String signStr,
                                              double hypoMean,
                                              DataDescription sampleDesc1,
                                              DataDescription sampleDesc2,
                                              double populationStddev1,
                                              double populationStddev2,
                                              double alpha)
        This method conducts a Z test for two population's difference of means when the populations' stddev values are known. Us knowing the populations' stddev values are usually an unrealistic assumption but sometimes they're known.
        This method finds exact results.
        This method is also used by the testForDiffOfMeansUnknownAny(String, double, DataDescription, DataDescription, double) method to get approximate resulsts when both the stddev values and the distribution type is unknown.
        This method has an additional parameter that's usually not used in daily statistics: `hypoMean`

        Usually we have 3 sets of difference of means:
        • H0 : xPar1 - xPar2 = 0
        • H0 : xPar1 - xPar2 >= 0
        • H0 : xPar1 - xPar2 <= 0
        Instead of always taking the right side of the equation as 0, this method takes it as hypoMean and calculates the result with that.
        The null hypothesis is specified with the signStr parameter:
        • if signStr is "=" then H0: xPar1 - xPar2 = hypoMean
        • if signStr is ">=" then H0: xPar1 - xPar2 >= hypoMean
        • if signStr is "<=" then H0: xPar1 - xPar2 <= hypoMean
        Parameters:
        signStr - ">=", "<=" or "=" to specify the sign of the inequality in the null hypothesis
        hypoMean - the hypothesized mean
        sampleDesc1 - first sample's description
        sampleDesc2 - second sample's description
        populationStddev1 - first population's known stddev value
        populationStddev2 - second population's known stddev value
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        true if the null hypothesis is accepted (the alternative hypothesis is rejected)

      • testForDiffOfMeansUnknownAny

        public static boolean testForDiffOfMeansUnknownAny(java.lang.String signStr,
                                                   double hypoMean,
                                                   DataDescription sampleDesc1,
                                                   DataDescription sampleDesc2,
                                                   double alpha)
        This method conducts a Z test for two population's difference of means when the populations' stddev values and the distributin type are unknown.
        This method finds approximate results by using the samples' stddev values as populations' stddev values.
        For more information look at testForDiffOfMeansKnown(String, double, DataDescription, DataDescription, double, double, double).
        Parameters:
        signStr - ">=", "<=" or "=" to specify the sign of the inequality in the null hypothesis
        hypoMean - the hypothesized mean
        sampleDesc1 - first sample's description
        sampleDesc2 - second sample's description
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        true if the null hypothesis is accepted (the alternative hypothesis is rejected)

      • testForDiffOfMeansUnknownNormal

        public static boolean testForDiffOfMeansUnknownNormal(java.lang.String signStr,
                                                      double hypoMean,
                                                      DataDescription sampleDesc1,
                                                      DataDescription sampleDesc2,
                                                      boolean assumeEqualStddevs,
                                                      double alpha)
        This method conducts a T test for two population's difference of means when the populations' stddev values are unknown and the populations are (approximately or exactly) normally distributed. This method finds exact results.
        The `hypoMean` parameter works the same as it was in the other methods.
        The `assumeEqualStddevs` parameter specifies if both populations have the same unknown stddev values or not.
        Parameters:
        signStr - ">=", "<=" or "=" to specify the sign of the inequality in the null hypothesis
        hypoMean - the hypothesized mean
        sampleDesc1 - first sample's description
        sampleDesc2 - second sample's description
        assumeEqualStddevs - specifies if both populations have the same unknown stddev values or not
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        true if the null hypothesis is accepted (the alternative hypothesis is rejected)

        public static boolean testForDiffOfMeansUnknownNormal(java.lang.String signStr,
                                                      double hypoMean,
                                                      double sampleCount1,
                                                      double sampleCount2,
                                                      double sampleMean1,

      • testForDifferenceOfProportions

        public static boolean testForDifferenceOfProportions(java.lang.String signStr,
                                                     double hypoProportion,
                                                     double sampleCount1,
                                                     double sampleCount2,
                                                     double sampleProportion1,
                                                     double sampleProportion2,
                                                     double alpha)
        This method conducts a Z test for two population's difference of proportions.
        This method has an additional parameter that's usually not used in daily statistics: `hypoProportion`

        Usually we have 3 sets of difference of proportions:
        • H0 : p1 - p2 = 0
        • H0 : p1 - p2 >= 0
        • H0 : p1 - p2 <= 0
        Instead of always taking the right side of the equation as 0, this method takes it as hypoProportion and calculates the result with that.
        The formula used to calculate the test statistics is as follows:

        z0 = ((pHat1 - pHat2) - hypoProportion) / sqrt( pw * qw * (1/n1 + 1/n2) )

        The null hypothesis is specified with the signStr parameter:
        • if signStr is "=" then H0: p1 - p2 = hypoProportion
        • if signStr is ">=" then H0: p1 - p2 >= hypoProportion
        • if signStr is "<=" then H0: p1 - p2 <= hypoProportion
        Parameters:
        signStr - ">=", "<=" or "=" to specify the sign of the inequality in the null hypothesis
        hypoProportion - the hypothesized proportion
        sampleCount1 - number of terms in the first sample
        sampleCount2 - number of terms in the second sample
        sampleProportion1 - the first sample's proportion value (successes / count)
        sampleProportion2 - the second sample's proportion value (successes / count)
        alpha - a value in range [0,1] specifying the confidence level, if you want %99 confidence level then you need to enter 0.01 (%1) as alpha
        Returns:
        true if the null hypothesis is accepted (the alternative hypothesis is rejected)
